Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650500 China Graphical abstract To investigate the mechanism of the role of active center size on the selectivity of methyl mercaptan (CH3SH) and methane (CH4) in the deep hydrogenation reaction of carbon disulfide (CS2), it was first derived from DFT calculations that the Pt cluster geometries showed a decreasing and increasing pattern on the energy barriers of the two key hydrogenation steps: (I) HCSS* to HCSSH* and (II) deep hydrogenation of CH2S* to CH3SH. For further validation, we synthesized Pt NPs with varied average sizes (1.7–4.0 nm) using a reduction-agglomeration strategy to probe the source of size sensitivity at low Pt loading. It was found that the active centers of Pt NPs located in the 2.0–3.0 nm region have the highest proportion of medium-coordinated Pt sites, which can effectively promote hydrogen spillover and enhance the HCSS* pathway. Finally, with this modulation strategy, the catalytic activity and selectivity were significantly improved at 1 wt% Pt loading, which exceeded that of the fresh 4 wt% Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, and the long-term stable production of CH3SH (selectivity was maintained at 80 %) was achieved at 250 ℃ in the high-concentration CS2 environment. Keywords CS2 hydrogenation Pt-based catalysts Size effect Hydrogen spillover CH3SH production Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon disulfide (CS2), a common volatile organosulfur species, is widely present in coke oven gas and viscose fiber industry exhaust gases in concentrations that are typically trace [1–4]. Organic sulfur compounds at only about 5 ppm can cause irreversible damage to the human respiratory system and kidneys and are often difficult to prevent due to their imperceptible odor [5,6]. CS2 emissions enter the atmosphere and undergo a complex photochemical reaction and chemical deposition to form sulfates, which contribute to the formation of acid rain [7]. Therefore, it is essential to control industrial emissions of trace organosulfur gases, which at the same time safeguards the degree of utilization of renewable industrial waste gases and dramatically improves the service life of downstream production catalysts. Direct conversion of CS2 to high value-added products CH3SH or CH4 is what we desire, while organic sulfur impurities have a strong adsorption capacity on the surface of noble metal-loaded catalysts and are catalyst poisons that can severely reduce or even completely inhibit the activity of supported metal catalysts [8]. For various complex sulfur-containing compounds that are difficult to remove, deep removal and generation of sulfur-free compounds can be achieved through hydrodesulfurization under pressurized conditions by taking advantage of the excellent hydrogen dissociation and spillover capability of noble metal catalysts [9–11]. Therefore, the utilization of residual hydrogen in coke oven gas [12] to realize the hydrogenation removal of CS2 is an effective means. For example, Kamp et al. [13] evaluated the ability of the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst to convert 100mol ppm CS2 at conditions of T = 150 ℃ and P = 1.2 bar and found that CS2 was completely eliminated, and the products were dominated by CH3SH and H2S but CH3SH selectivity did not exceed 30 % with elemental carbon being deposited mainly as coke on the catalyst. As the temperature increased to 200 ℃, the CH3SH product was almost undetectable. For the CS2 hydrogenation reaction at higher temperatures, Chen et al. [14] synthesized a magnesium-carbon composite hydrogen storage catalyst, which can convert CS2 to CH4 and H2S at 350 ℃ in the absence of high-pressure gaseous H2 and achieved a conversion rate of more than 99.1 % within 300 min, but did not provide CH4 selectivity data. Despite the complete conversion of CS2 by these catalysts, there is a lack of in-depth studies on the controlled modulation of product selectivity. The use of CS2 as resources at T = 260 ℃ and P = 0.3 MPa for the synthesis of the methionine feedstock CH3SH is feasible [15], and the reaction is more advantageous if it can be realized at atmospheric pressure. Pt/Al2O3 catalysts have been demonstrated to have low coke selectivity (≤10 %) in CS2 hydrogenation reaction [16]. Normally, platinum (Pt), palladium (Pd), and other noble metals typically have optimal hydrogen dissociation capabilities in the metallic state, and monoatomic dispersed Pt species possesses poor hydrogen dissociation ability [16–18]. Therefore, regulation of the existence state of metallic Pt on noble metal-based catalysts is critical to enhance the CH3SH and CH4 selectivity for CS2 hydrogenation. Pt NPs size has salient effects on the hydrogen dissociation and hydrogenation reaction paths, there is a high demand for the synthesis of size-tunable metal catalysts on supports with similar surface physical and chemical properties to obtain the specified products. Wet-impregnation method is widely used to control the size of metal nanoparticles by adjusting the loading of metal precursors and/or the surface properties of the supports. For example, active ingredients with different dispersions could be acquired by taking advantage of differences in supports properties or by special pretreatment of the supports. Sun et al. [19] utilized the properties discrepancies of CeZrO2 and Al2O3 to form Pt NPs with different sizes, and Cao et al. [20] treated CeO2 nanorods with different concentrations of ascorbic acid (AA) to obtain support with an incremental concentration of Ce3+ and thus obtained larger Pd NPs size. However, differences in catalyst surface properties and metal-support interactions can also make catalyst comparisons uncertain. Highly dispersed Pt atoms can sinter and agglomerate into larger clusters by a “reduction-aggregation” strategy [21], thus the Pt NPs size can be modulated by changing the H2 pretreatment temperature, and the properties of the irreducible support Al2O3 are not changed and the occurrence of SMSI is avoided. Towards improving the selectivity of the CH3SH and CH4 products, we have deeply analyzed the particle size sensitivity of CS2 hydrogenation using a “reduction-agglomeration” strategy in a suitable temperature interval (400–700 ℃) guided by the predictions of DFT computational modeling and taking advantage of the property of the Pt atoms to attract each other to agglomerate in a high-temperature reducing atmosphere. In addition, High-angle annular dark-field STEM (HAADF-STEM) images, powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and CO-DRIFTS measurements were used to investigate the dispersion states and electronic states of the Pt species. Finally, the correlation between the CS2 hydrogenation mechanism and the Pt NPs size over 1Pt/Al-xH catalysts was investigated using in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Nano γ-Al2O3 (10 nm) and H2PtCl6 solution (8 wt% in water) are purchased from Aladdin Limited Company, China. All materials are not subjected to further purification. WO3 were purchased from Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Deionized water was used in the entire experimental process. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pt loading (0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 4 wt%) were prepared by conventional impregnation methods. The samples were prepared by adding 0.01 M HCl solution to ensure the pH of the mixed solution was weakly acidic. Typically, the 5 g nano γ-Al2O3 powder (≥200 mesh, 10 nm) were dispersed in H2PtCl6 (8 wt.% in water, 1.25 mL, 0.05 g for 1 wt%) aqueous solution, stirred for 3 h at room temperature and evaporated at 80 ℃ in a rotary evaporator, and then dried overnight at 100 ℃. The powder products were calcined at 500 ℃ for 3 h under an air atmosphere to obtain the desired 1Pt/Al-fresh catalyst. The calcined powder samples (40–60 mesh) were reduced at 400 °C to 800 °C under H2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and maintained for 2 h, which were denoted as 1Pt/Al-TH (T refers to the reduction temperature). 2.3 Characterization High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images and High-angle annular dark-field STEM (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on an FEI Talos F200S TEM instrument equipped with an EDX analyzer at an acceleration voltage of 1−20 kV. Powder XRD (Bruker D8 Advance) measurements of the catalysts were diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15406 nm). The patterns were taken over the 2θ range from 10 to 80◦ at a scan speed of 2◦/min. XPS (Thermo Fisher Scientific K-alpha)’s X-ray light source is a monochromatic Al Kα source (Mono Al Kα, 1486.6 eV). The basic site of the material is determined by CO2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD) through the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. During measuring, the 50 mg sample was pretreated in a He atmosphere at 300 ℃ for 60 min firstly and then exposed to CO2/He at 25 ℃ for 1 h. Finally, the temperature was increased to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃ /min under He atmosphere, the gas concentration was monitored by a TCD detector. Similarly, H2-TPD (H2 Temperature programmed desorption) was carried out on the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument, the 50 mg sample was pretreated in a He atmosphere at 300 ℃ for 1 h firstly, then the mixture of 10 % H2/Ar was introduced at 25 ℃ for 1 h until saturation, and finally, the gas was desorbed at a temperature increase rate of 10 ℃/min to 800 ℃ under Ar atmosphere, and the gas was detected by TCD. The CO chemisorption of catalysts was recorded at 50 °C by using CO pulse chemisorption on Autochem II 2920 chemisorption. The sample (∼100 mg) was pretreated with hydrogen at desired temperatures for 1 h, followed by purging with high purity He for 30 min. After cooling down to 50 °C, a 5 % CO/He mixture was injected into the reactor repeatedly until CO adsorption was saturated. The Pt dispersion was calculated based on the chemically adsorbed CO and the practical amount of Pt in the catalysts with the assumption that CO: Pt is 1:1. In situ DRIFTS spectra of CO or H2 adsorption were collected on a Thermo iS50 infrared spectrometer with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector and a transmission cell. Before the measurement, each catalyst was pretreated at a desired temperature under a flowing H2 atmosphere (100 mL/min) for 1 h. The catalyst was subsequently cooled down to room temperature (CO) or 200 °C (H2) under a flowing N2 atmosphere (100 mL/min). After evacuating for 30 min and collecting background, the spectrum was recorded in 1 % CO/N2 or 10 % H2/N2 gas flow, which was introduced to the catalyst at room temperature (CO) or 200 °C (H2). In situ DRIFTS measurements for CS2 hydrogenation were conducted using Thermo iS50 infrared spectrometer with an MCT detector and a flow-type quartz IR cell connected to a flow system. The 1Pt/Al-TH samples were heated under a flow of 10 % H2/N2 (100 mL/min) at 400 °C for 120 min before the measurement. The background spectrum was recorded after switching the gas to pure N2, followed by the IR spectra recorded under a 200 ppm CS2 (10 % H2, balanced with N2, 100 mL/min) flow at 250 °C for 30 min. Afterward, the IR cell was purged with pure N2 (100 mL/min) for 1 min and switched to 10 % H2/N2 (100 mL/min) at 250 °C for 30 min. 2.4 Catalyst performance test The catalytic hydrogenation reaction of CS2 was conducted in a fixed bed reactor (i.d. 4 mm), and the entire reaction process uses catalyst particles pressed into 40–60 mesh. 1 % CS2/N2 cylinder gas is used as raw gas, and the CS2 concentration is controlled by flow rate regulation. Pure hydrogen comes from the electrolysis of water in the hydrogen generator. A simulated gas stream composed of CS2 (200 ppm), H2 (10 vol%), and balance N2 with the gas flow rate of 100 mL/min and the volume space velocity of 200,000 mL/gcatal∙h. The concentration of CS2, H2S, and CH3SH was detected with gas chromatography (GC-9790II, Zhejiang Fuli Analytical Instrument Co., Ltd, China) with a flame photometric detector (FPD) under the following conditions: capillary chromatographic column (RB-PLOT Q), the oven temperature was 80°C and detector temperature was 250 °C. The concentration of CO and CH4 was detected with gas chromatography (GC-9790II, Zhejiang Fuli Analytical Instrument Co., Ltd, China) with a flame ionization detector (FID) equipped with a methanation furnace under the following conditions: capillary chromatographic column (RB-PLOT Q), the oven temperature was 80 °C and detector temperature was 250 °C. Among them, the concentration of CO is indirectly quantified using a methanation furnace. The selectivity of CH3SH, CH4 and CO is calculated based on the number of C atoms, and the selectivity of H2S is calculated based on the number of S atoms. The calculations formulas of the CS2 conversion, the selectivity of generated H2S, CO, CH3SH, and CH4, and S balance are described as follows (Eqs. (2-1)–(2-6)): (2-1) C S 2 conversion (%)= C S 2in -C S 2out C S 2in × 100% (2-2) C H 3 SH selectivity (%)= C H 3 S H out C S 2in -C S 2out × 100% (2-3) C H 4 selectivity (%)= C H 4out C S 2in -C S 2out × 100% (2-4) CO selectivity (%)= C O out C S 2in -C S 2out × 100% (2-5) H 2 S selectivity (%)= 1 2 H 2 S out C S 2in -C S 2out × 100% (2-6) S balance (%)= 1 2 H 2 S out + 1 2 C H 3 S H out C S 2in -C S 2out × 100% 2.5 DFT calculations Details of the density functional theory calculations can be found in Supporting information S1 section. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 DFT calculations of reaction pathway for CH3SH formation over different Pt cluster models As the key intermediates for the generation of CH3SH and CH4 on Pt-based catalysts have been found to be HCSS* and CH2S* species in our previous studies [16], thus, we first analyzed the size effect of Pt NPs on the generation of different pivotal intermediates of CS2 hydrogenation by DFT calculations. Due to the variations in geometric configurations of Pt clusters of varied sizes, this can have an impact on the adsorption and further hydrogenation of CS2 molecules. To explore the influence of Pt cluster size on the energy barrier of the key step of CS2 hydrogenation, we chose to construct Pt19, Pt55, Pt92 and Pt135 models presenting a certain gradient, which can fully represent the crucial effect of the geometrical configuration change. As shown in Fig. 1 a, and their adsorption energies to CS2 showed a tendency of decreasing and then increasing, so that the appropriate Pt cluster sizes could enhance sulfur-resistant performance. Because of the spontaneous dissociation of H2 on Pt clusters, we calculated the intermediate adsorbates for four model hydrogenation processes. Taken as a whole (Fig. 1a), the steps that determined the generation of CH3SH consist of two, (I) HCSS* hydrogenation to HCSSH* and (II) deep hydrogenation of CH2S* to CH3SH*. We counted the energy of each intermediate (Fig. 1c), and for the rate-determining step of generating formic acid, Pt19 had a maximum energy barrier of 0.771 eV, and the energy barrier decreased with increasing particle size. On Pt135, the energy barrier is even negative (−0.41 eV). For the conversion step of CH2S* to CH3SH, there was just the opposite trend, the largest energy barrier appeared on Pt135 at 0.845 eV, while the energy barrier on Pt19 is −0.21 eV. It is not difficult to conclude that the energy barriers of two main rate-determining steps have the opposite trend with the Pt cluster size, and there is an optimal Pt cluster size to ensure the most efficient reaction. The curves of the energy barrier changing with the Pt clusters size are intersected (Fig. 1b), and there is just an intersection point, that is, the Pt cluster containing 75 Pt atoms may have the best CH3SH generation ability. The smaller Pt cluster system like Pt19 adsorbed CS2 strongly, but it was difficult to continue the conversion to the effective intermediate HCSSH*, which limited the generation of CH3SH from the beginning of the reaction and may lead to the occurrence of additional side reactions (formation of coke). Larger clusters, such as Pt92, have moderate CS2 adsorption strength and rapidly generate CH2S* intermediates under H-atom attack, with the main rate-controlling step determined in the generation of CH3SH. A key hydrogenation step of small and large clusters is limited by relatively higher energy barriers, and medium-sized Pt clusters are more effective in converting CS2 to CH3SH under fixed energy input conditions. The results of theoretical calculations therefore revealed a certain particle size (geometry) sensitivity in the product selectivity of CS2 hydrogenation. 3.2 Synthesis of Pt NPs with different sizes The results of theoretical calculations confirm the effect of Pt particle geometry (size) on the reaction path energy barriers, but in practice the reaction is still governed by various factors, such as the size effect of Pt NPs real sites, and the effect of particle size on the hydrogen dissociation behavior (which could not be fully taken into account during the DFT calculations due to the spontaneous dissociation of hydrogen). Therefore, we prepared Pt NPs-loaded Al2O3 catalysts with different sizes by adopting a reduction-agglomeration strategy to deeply analyze the relationship between dimension and activity and product selectivity. Treatment of Al2O3 based catalysts under high-temperature H2 conditions does not change the nature of the support and can modulate the size of Pt NPs [22]. On the 1Pt/Al catalyst without reduction treatment, it can be found that the Pt atoms are well dispersed, and all Pt atoms exist as single atoms or small clusters (Fig. 2 a). H2 reduction at different temperatures caused varying degrees of agglomeration of Pt atoms (Fig. S1), the size of the Pt NPs increased between 1–5 nm (Fig. 2b–e) and the dispersion decreased from 83.5 % to 28.3 % (Table S1, CO pulse chemisorption) as the reduction temperature increased (0–700 ℃). The Pt species were stably anchored to the terminal hydroxyl groups of the Al2O3 support, resulting in single atom-level dispersion. Treatment with high-temperature H2 can lead to delocalization of Pt atoms from the anchoring sites, breaking of the PtO bond, and increased interaction between Pt atoms to aggregate into Pt NPs [21,23]. The Pt NPs on the surface of 1Pt/Al-400H were more homogeneous and the particle sizes were small concentrated between 1.5–2.0 nm, with an average value of 1.75 nm. On the surface of 1Pt/Al-500H, Pt NPs mostly distributed in the 2.0–3.0 nm region and the average size of the particles reached 2.70 nm. When the temperature was raised to 600 and 700 ℃, the average size of the Pt NPs reached 3.3 and 4.0 nm respectively, and majority of the particles concentrated between 3.0–4.0 nm and 3.5–5.0 nm respectively. It is worth noting that due to the low loading and the absence of a particularly large degree of agglomeration of the Pt atoms, the associated peaks of the Pt NPs were not observed in the XRD spectra (Figs. 2f and S3), only the characteristic peaks of γ-Al2O3 were found [24]. But lattice fringes of the Pt (111) plane are exposed in the TEM, with a lattice distance of d = 0.231 nm on 1Pt/Al-500H sample (Fig. S2) [25]. Therefore, under the condition of limited loading of Pt, it is of immense importance to increase the particle size of Pt by adjusting the reduction temperature, especially applied in the reaction under reducing atmosphere. Conversely, the conventional roasting method cannot guarantee the stability of the formed Pt NPs, which may be re-dispersed into small Pt clusters under a high temperature reducing atmosphere. 3.3 Activity and products selectivity of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different sizes 1Pt/Al catalysts with different particle sizes obtained by reduction-agglomeration strategy were applied in the reaction of CS2 hydrogenation. It was obvious that the CS2 hydrogenation activity, CH3SH at 250 ℃, and CH4 selectivity at 350 ℃ of 1Pt/Al-TH catalysts increased and then decreased with the Pt NPs (Fig. 3 a–c). The other major gaseous products are H2S and CO (Fig. S4), and the sulfur balance of the entire reaction is more than 95 %. Medium-sized Pt NPs (2.0–3.0 nm) have better CS2 conversion and CH3SH and CH4 selectivity, and either smaller (1.5–2.0 nm) or larger Pt particles (3.0–5.0 nm) are not favorable for deep hydrogenation of CS2 and increase the generation of by-products CO (Fig. S4) and coke. In addition, we compared the activity changes of Pt/Al-TH catalysts with different loadings (Figs. S5a and S5b). As the Pt loading was decreased to 0.2 wt% and 0.5 wt%, the reduction temperatures required to reach the optimal activity increased to 900 °C and 800 °C, respectively, at which point the 0.2Pt/Al-900H catalyst may not have reached the inflection point. The decrease in the number of Pt atoms at low loadings required higher temperatures to agglomerate into medium Pt NPs. To verify the synergistic effect of Pt NPs with various sizes, we physically mixed 1Pt/Al-xH (400, 500, 800, representing small, medium, and large Pt NPs respectively) with different size distributions in equal proportions, and compared the activity and selectivity with 1Pt/Al-500H. As presented in Fig. S6, the CS2 activity and CH3SH, CH4 selectivity of 1Pt/Al-mixH with various particle size distributions at 250–300 ℃ are lower than those of 1Pt/Al-500H. It was expected that if there was synergy, the activity should be equivalent or better, but the results did not match the synergistic effect. Nevertheless, due to the higher number of active centers for the optimal particle size, we found that the 1Pt/Al-500H catalysts showed better activity at 250 °C relative to 0.2Pt/Al-900H and 0.5Pt/Al-800H. By modulating the particle size, 1Pt/Al-500H showed enhanced activity, even exceeding the activity of 4Pt-fresh (Fig. S5c) with CH3SH and CH4 selectivity reaching 79 % (250 ℃) and 85 % (350 ℃) respectively (Fig. 3b and c). In general agreement with the DFT prediction, the synthesized Pt clusters with an average particle size of 2.7 nm showed the best CH3SH, CH4 selectivity and CS2 hydrogenation activity. Fitness adjustment by reduction temperature and Pt loading played a key role in the enhancement of CS2 hydrogenation activity and selectivity. Moreover, the CS2 conversion of 2Pt/Al-500H and 4Pt/Al-500H at 250 °C was only 70–80 % (Fig. S4d). In conjunction with the DFT calculations, the possible reason is that as the Pt loading is increased to 2 and 4 wt%, larger Pt NPs are formed at the same reduction temperature, but fewer Pt NPs are distributed in the appropriate size range (2.0–3.0 nm), which is unsuitable for the conversion of the CH2S* species to CH3SH. Thus, despite the large increase in the number of active centers, the 2Pt/Al-500H and 4Pt/Al-500H do not show a significant increase in CS2 conversion. To compare the turnover frequency (TOF) of individual active sites, the reaction conversion was uniformly controlled below 20 %, the 1Pt/Al-700H sample has the highest TOF of 0.833 S−1 (Table S1) and there showed a negative correlation between TOF and dispersion (Fig. 3d). In general, since the total number of Pt atoms is certain, the performance of 1Pt/Al-TH is affected by the number of active sites and the Pt NPs size, which results in a volcano-shaped curve of CH3SH selectivity as a function of particle size. Also, the Arrhenius curves (Fig. 3e) showed that 1Pt/Al-500H had the lowest activation energy (Ea = 67.195 kJ/mol), which was consistent with the activity evaluation results. However, it was worth noting that the number of H2 reaction orders increased with the average particle size, reaching 0.708 for 1Pt/Al-600H catalyst (Fig. S7), revealing that the larger Pt NPs are more sensitive to the H2 concentration and facilitate dissociating H2, which was one of the probable reasons for the lower energy barriers of the HCSS*-HCSSH* step. Subsequently, we examined the stability of the CS2 hydrogenation reaction at different temperatures, respectively. Both the reactant concentration and catalyst mass were scaled up to investigate whether the catalyst has the potential to stably produce the high value-added product CH3SH at 250 ℃. As shown in Fig. 3f, the CS2 conversion of 1Pt/Al-500H decreased from the initial 87 % to 78 % after 1500 min of reaction, but the selectivity of each product remained stable, the accumulation of intermediate products led to a decrease in activity. As shown in Fig. S8, after 24h of reaction at higher temperature (300 and 350 ℃), the catalyst activity decreased from 100 % to 93 % at 300 ℃ and maintained for 100 % at 350 ℃, which possessed stability in prolonged CS2 removal. Under high temperature conditions (350 ℃), the main product of CS2 hydrogenation is CH4 (selectivity 85 %), and the S balance is close to 100 %, which is suitable for long-term deep removal of CS2 in coke oven gas. Meanwhile, STEM and mapping characterization of the spent sample (Fig. S9) showed that the average particle size of the Pt NPs did not change significantly, with a value of 2.8 nm. 3.4 Electronic states and existing sites analysis of Pt species The high-temperature H2 reduction pretreatment can break the Pt-O bond and transform the oxidized Pt to the metallic state, forming Pt0 nanoparticles with different particle sizes. XPS spectra of Pt 4d were analyzed to understand the effect of increasing particle size on the chemical state of Pt species (Figs. 4a and S10). In the 1Pt/Al catalyst, the binding energy (BE) of Pt 4d5/2 was concentrated around 316.0 eV, indicating that the Pt species existed in the oxidized state (Ptσ+) [26]; after hydrogen reduction, the binding energy of the main peak of Pt 4d5/2 was continuously redshifted to around 314.2 eV, indicating that Ptσ+ progressively gained electrons and was reduced to Pt0 [27]. For 1Pt/Al, a peak splitting, two peaks can be clearly observed, belonging to Pt4+ near 317.2 eV and Pt2+ near 315.0 eV [27–29]. Nevertheless, a new Pt BE value of 1Pt/Al-400H, 1Pt/Al-500H, and 1Pt/Al-600H appeared (313.0, 312.9, and 312.8 eV, respectively), and the electronic energy levels were attributed to the Pt0 BE [26,27], which implied that the formation of enlarged Pt0 NPs. As the temperature of H2 treatment raised (400–600 ℃), the proportion of metallic Pt increased from 31.6 % to 55.2 %, implying that the increase in particle size was accompanied by the generation of more Pt0 species. Meanwhile, the decreasing XPS intensity of Pt 4d with increasing reduction temperature suggested a decline in the concentration of Pt species dispersed on the catalyst surface and the formation of larger Pt NPs (Fig. S10). In addition, the XPS survey analysis of the deactivated 1Pt/Al-500H was carried out. As presented in Fig. S11, the reason for the deactivation was that some of the Pt0 was oxidized to Pt2+ (Pt0 percentage decreased from 43.1 % to 27.3 %) under the continuous decomposition of CS2 and the formation of PtS [30], which resulted in the reduction of the Pt0 active centers for hydrogen dissociation. The dispersion state and electronic environment of Pt species on Al2O3 were verified using CO-DRIFTS at room temperature (Fig. 4 b–e). 1Pt/Al showed four peaks centered at 2139 cm−1 (CO linearly adsorbed on single-atom Pt species (CO-Ptδ+)), near 2089 cm−1 (CO linearly adsorbed on well-coordinated Pt (terrace sites), coordinated numbers (CN) ≥ 8), near 2043 cm−1 (CO linearly adsorbed on under-coordinated Pt (edge or corner sites), CN ≤ 6), and near 1844 cm−1 (bridged CO adsorption on medium-coordinated step sites, CN = 6–8) [31–34]. 1Pt/Al was not observed to have significant nanoparticles formation in the TEM images, but due to the extreme susceptibility of the oxidized state of Pt to be given electrons by reducing gas CO, the bridged adsorption peaks of CO appeared. It can be observed that the CO adsorption peaks of the H2-pretreated samples all shift to lower wavenumbers, which is attributed to the enrichment of electrons on Pt species. Moreover, the percentage of CO bridged adsorption peaks area on 1Pt/Al-400H, 1Pt/Al-500H, and 1Pt/Al-600H increased to 19.7 %, 40.5 %, and 30.1 %, and the proportions of well-coordinated Pt species were 23.6 %, 20.6 %, and 27.6 % respectively, which suggested the formation of continuous Pt (111) facets and larger nanoparticles. As the size of Pt NPs continued to enlarge, the under-coordinated Pt sites gradually shifted to medium-coordinated and well-coordinated Pt species [31,33,34], among which 1Pt/Al-500H exhibited the highest proportion of step sites (40.5 %) exposure. The increase in terrace sites (27.6 %) of 1Pt/Al-600H was accompanied by a decrease in step sites (30.1 %), which meant that the coordination number continued to increase as a function of NP size, and the number of Pt atoms located at the Pt-Al interface should also decrease accordingly. 3.5 Hydrogen adsorption behavior and spillover capacity analysis To investigate the effect of the Pt-Al interface on the adsorption and dissociation of H2, we constructed a Pt19/Al2O3 (100) model to analyze the differences in the behavior of H2 adsorption and dissociation on the surface of Pt19 clusters and at the Pt-Al interface (Fig. S12). It can be observed that a H2 molecule spontaneously dissociates either when they are placed at the top atom of the Pt19 cluster or near the Pt-Al interface. When the distance of a H2 molecule from the Pt19 cluster is increased, adsorption configurations appear at the apical position and at the Pt-Al interface, with adsorption energies of −0.009 eV and −0.04 eV, respectively. The very small adsorption energies imply that H2 is active at both positions and tends to desorb or dissociate. Therefore, the Pt-Al interface is not decisive for H2 dissociation. Subsequently, H2 adsorption behavior and spillover capacity of 1Pt/Al catalysts with different particle sizes were investigated. H2-TPD tests were operated for different samples after adsorption saturation at room temperature. Three desorption peaks can be observed in Fig. 5 a, centered at 150 ℃, 350 ℃ and ≥ 450 ℃, which were attributed to the detachment of metal weakly metal-bonded hydrogen, metal strongly bonded hydrogen, and spillover hydrogen from the Al2O3 support [16,35–38]. On 1Pt/Al and 1Pt/Al-400H, hydrogen was bonded to metal Pt and hardly spilled outward, while on 1Pt/Al-500H and 1Pt/Al-600H hydrogen spillover was more active and a desorption peak with higher temperatures appeared. After pretreatment of 1Pt/Al with hydrogen reduction at different temperatures, CO2-TPD tests were performed on the samples to determine the extent of H spillover laterally by observing the desorption peak located near 430 ℃ (Fig. 5b). Since hydrogen was usually stored on the non-reducible support Al2O3 in the form of H/OH pairs after spillover, which can be used as moderate adsorption sites for CO2 molecules [39,40], and the significant increase in peak area of the moderate basic sites on 1Pt/Al-500H confirmed the level of H spillover. Subsequently, the H spillover capacity of various samples was investigated by reducing a mixture of WO3 and catalyst with H2 at room temperature. The reaction mechanism is that WO3 combines with the H overflow from the catalyst to form HxWO3, and the color changes from yellow to dark green [41,42], hence, the H spillover ability can be judged by the degree of color change. As shown in Fig. 5c, the color of 1Pt/Al remained unchanged for 12 min, while 1Pt/Al-500H changed to dark green in 4 min and 1Pt/Al-600H for 8 min. Furthermore, the H2-DRIFTS (Fig. 5d) was conducted at 200 °C on the 1Pt/Al and 1Pt/Al-xH samples to observe the evolution of OH stretching (observed at ∼3450−3550 cm−1), which was an indicator of hydrogen spillover on Al2O3 [43]. The results showed that the 1Pt/Al-500H and 1Pt/Al-600H catalysts clearly exhibited the evolution of OH stretching, while the 1Pt/Al and 1Pt/Al-400H catalysts were negligible. Briefly, it can be concluded that hydrogen spillovers are more active on catalysts with Pt NPs sizes located between 2.0–3.0 nm compared to unreduced 1Pt/Al and smaller or larger Pt NPs loaded catalysts, which is also corroborated by H2-TPD, CO2-TPD and WO3 discoloration experiments. In summary, combining the XPS and CO-DRIFTS results, the hydrogen spillover ability of the catalyst also has a size effect, rather than being controlled by the number of Pt0 (well-coordinated Pt terrace sites) or Pt-Al interface number. That is, medium-coordinated Pt species (Pt step sites) are more conducive to the dissociation and overflow of hydrogen, which is also an important factor in improving the performance of CS2 hydrogenation. 3.6 In situ DRIFTS mechanistic study of CS2 hydrogenation The H2 reaction orders (Fig. 3e) and the efficiency of hydrogen spillovers (Fig. 5) do not have the same dependence on Pt NPs size, and the H2 reaction order is more sensitive to the amount of Pt0. Our previous studies have found that hydrogen spillover promotes the hydrogenation of HCSS* to CH2S* on the H/OH pairs of the support [16], which may serve as an auxiliary reaction pathway. To further verify the effects of the particle size of Pt NPs on the key intermediates and reaction mechanisms of the CS2 hydrogenation reaction, in situ DRIFTS experiments on 1Pt/Al-xH catalysts were conducted at 250 ℃. Before the test, all samples were first pretreated at 400 °C for 1 h under 10 % H2/N2 atmosphere. As shown in Figs. S13 and S14, several characteristic peaks appeared during the reaction: the SCS vibration of the bidentate HCSS* at 1345 cm−1 and the SCS vibration of the monodentate HCSS* at 1596 cm−1 [44–46], the CH vibration assigned to the CH2S* species at 2918 cm−1 [30], and the adsorbed CS2* at 1525 and 1540 cm−1 [47,48], as well as the CH vibrations attributed to the product CH3S* and CH4 species near 2982 cm−1 and 3014 cm−1 [49,50], respectively. When CS2 was adsorbed on the surface of 1Pt/Al-400H, it reacted with the surface H2O species (3389 cm−1) on Al2O3 to generate carbonate (HCSO2 −) species located near 1470 cm−1 [51], which proved that H/OH pairs were not generated through hydrogen spillover during the pretreatment process, thus led to the occurrence of the hydrolysis side reaction of CS2. In contrast, relatively more H/OH pairs remained on 1Pt/Al-500H and 1Pt/Al-600H, which contributed to the observation of the generation of a weak CH2S* species at 2915 or 2920 cm−1, and the intensity of this species increased after H2 passages. This phenomenon confirmed that the conversion of HCSS* to CH2S* species was positively correlated with the concentration of residual H/OH species on the Al2O3. After hydrogen injection, the H/OH pairs on 1Pt/Al-500H and 1Pt/Al-600H were replenished and strengthened until stabilized; whereas the change of this species on the surface of 1Pt/Al-400H was negligible, and only the accumulation of the intermediate bidentate HCSS* (1350 cm−1), was noticed, which highlighted that hydrogen spillover capacity of the catalyst was particularly critical for the generation of CH2S*. Subsequently the catalyst surface reaction was carried out using actual reaction conditions (200 ppm CS2 + 10 % H2). As shown in Figs. 6 and S14, the change of surface intermediates of 1Pt/Al-400H was insignificant, and only a slight generation of CH2S* was observed; according to DFT calculations, smaller Pt clusters are unfavorable for HCSSH* generation and then CH2S* formation, thus, the intensity of CH2S* species were not as much as that of 1Pt/Al-500H (600H) with larger Pt NPs size. Indeed, 1Pt/Al-400H has difficulty in efficiently converting HCSS* to CH2S* due to the small particle size of the Pt NPs, which leads to almost no subsequent products. While on 1Pt/Al-600H, although CH2S* was continuously generated and accumulated through the HCSS* pathway, it was still sticky to convert to CH3SH and CH4 due to the higher energy barrier of the CH2S*-CH3SH step on the larger Pt NPs, as well as the lack of spilled H2. Conversely, on 1Pt/Al-500H, a first increase and then decrease in CH2S* and CH3S* species can be observed, with CH3SH and CH4 products maintaining the same trend. This suggests that the energy barriers for both the generation of HCSSH* from HCSS* and CH3SH from CH2S* on 1Pt/Al-500H are moderate; meanwhile, the Pt NPs in the 2.0–3.0 nm region have the strongest hydrogen spillover capacity, which is favorable for the conversion of HCSS* to CH2S* and CH3SH. Therefore, the excellent selectivity stems from the moderate reaction energy barriers of rate-determining steps and the good hydrogen spillover ability, which are both related to the Pt NPs size. Based on DFT calculations and in situ DRIFTS results in this work and our previous research [16], the specific CH3SH and CH4 formation mechanisms are as follows (Eqs. (3–1) to (3–7)): (3-1) 4 H 2 → 8 H ∗ (3-2) C S 2 ad + H ∗ → H C S 2 ∗ ad (3-3) H C S 2 ∗ ad +2 H ∗ → C H 2 S ∗ ad +H S ∗ (3-4) C H 2 S ∗ ad +2 H ∗ → C H 3 SH (3-5) H S ∗ + H ∗ → H 2 S (3-6) C H 2 S ∗ ad +3 H ∗ → C H 4 +H S ∗ (3-7) 2H S ∗ + 2H ∗ → 2H 2 S Among them, steps (3–3) and (3–4) are the key rate-determining steps for the generation of CH3SH, while CH2S* and CH3S* are the crucial intermediates. At high temperatures, CH2S* is prone to directly deep hydrogenation to CH4. 4 Conclusions Gaseous organic sulfur compounds are not only directly hazardous to human health but are also important precursors of PM2.5 and ozone, as well as toxic to downstream reactors and catalysts in industrial production. Catalytic hydrogenation is one of the most effective methods for deep cleaning of industrial emissions of organic sulfur. Due to the presence of high concentration of methane (23–27 %) in coke oven gas, it is thermodynamically more feasible to convert CS2 into CH3SH for recycling, and the required temperature is lower. In addition, CH3SH (up to 500 mg/m3) generated under highly selective conditions can be liquefied and recycled as a raw material to produce methionine, which is more advantageous than the traditional technology of converting CO, H2 and H2S into methyl mercaptan under pressurized conditions, and has the potential to be used as an alternative synthesis route. Here, the key steps of CS2 hydrogenation (I) HCSS* − HCSSH and (II) CH2S* − CH3SH were found to be sensitive to Pt clusters size by DFT calculations, and highly dispersed Pt atoms on Al2O3 were aggregated into different sizes of Pt NPs by the reduction-aggregation method, among which the average particle size of 1Pt/Al-500H was 2.7 nm, which had the best low-temperature activity and CH3SH selectivity, with the activity even exceeding that of 4Pt/Al, and the product selectivity (80–85 %) remained stable in the 24 h experiment at 250 ℃. The following two points are summarized from the DFT calculations and experimental results: (1) 1Pt/Al-500H forms the best-sized active centers (2.0–3.0 nm) of Pt NPs and has the largest proportion of exposed moderate coordinated sites (step sites, CN = 6–8), which enhances the efficiency of hydrogen spillover to the supports after dissociation; (2) the medium-sized Pt NPs with moderate energy barriers in both key hydrogenation steps, together with the spilled hydrogen-assisted monodentate HCSS* pathway, performing the best activity and CH3SH and CH4 selectivity. We have analyzed the source of particle size sensitivity about the volatile organic sulfur pollutants (VOSPs) hydrogenation product selectivity from a new perspective, which provides innovative guides for the subsequent design of rationally sized noble metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: To investigate the mechanism of the role of active center size on the selectivity of methyl mercaptan (CH3SH) and methane (CH4) in the deep hydrogenation reaction of carbon disulfide (CS2), it was first derived from DFT calculations that the Pt cluster geometries showed a decreasing and increasing pattern on the energy barriers of the two key hydrogenation steps: (I) HCSS* to HCSSH* and (II) deep hydrogenation of CH2S* to CH3SH. For further validation, we synthesized Pt NPs with varied average sizes (1.7–4.0 nm) using a reduction-agglomeration strategy to probe the source of size sensitivity at low Pt loading. It was found that the active centers of Pt NPs located in the 2.0–3.0 nm region have the highest proportion of medium-coordinated Pt sites, which can effectively promote hydrogen spillover and enhance the HCSS* pathway. Finally, with this modulation strategy, the catalytic activity and selectivity were significantly improved at 1 wt% Pt loading, which exceeded that of the fresh 4 wt% Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, and the long-term stable production of CH3SH (selectivity was maintained at 80 %) was achieved at 250 ℃ in the high-concentration CS2 environment.
